When I was 8 years I lost my cousin, Reggie, to gun violence. It was right after Christmas. He was more like a brother than a cousin to me since my mom and grandmother helped to raise him when he was young. He was the apple of everybody’s eye. I remember learning about where in the street he was murdered and how they took his tennis shoes and starter jacket. His killer was never found, and the pain that resulted remains deep. My story is not an isolated one and sheds light to the need to have sensible broad gun violence policies in our country. We must recognize that gun violence is a broad issue and needs to be tackled with solutions that address killings ranging from suicide, domestic homicides, murders like my cousin’s, mass shootings, and those in between. For a long time gun violence prevention was not on the radar, and after Columbine (when I was in high school) it began to be more widely discussed. Sadly, we have even seen children become activists on this issue in order to try to make progress. Families and communities everywhere are counting on us to do more than just talk about these issues, we must do something now and not just remain stuck in a debate. This picture was taken at my 2016 Swearing-In as an At-Large Houston City Council Member. In that moment, I was excited, optimistic & trying to be very careful to not slip on the Jones Hall Stage (many people don’t know that I can be a little clumsy). I remember my shy mother being nervous as we waited backstage and then how excited she was once we walked onstage. I am grateful to her for her unconditional love & strength as she has been my rock. I love her dearly & could not have had anyone better to walk that stage with me - I now pray for her continued strength as she is battling cancer. To say that it has been tough is an understatement, but we will persevere. I am grateful to have been elected to serve the 2.3 million Houstonians that now hold a permanent space in my heart. To every person that would pick up the phone when I would seek to partner with you in the community, THANK YOU. . . To all of the people that called the city & my office and allowed us the opportunity to serve them & restore their confidence that someone in gov’t could help, THANK YOU. . . To the staff, volunteers & interns who worked to achieve our office mission to make Houston the place where the Gulf Coast & the World’s future meet & to treat residents the same way you would want someone to treat your grandmother, THANK YOU. . . To every entrepreneur, ecosystem builder, collaborator, resident, thought parter, the mayor, colleague, community stakeholder & advocate who joined me to have a seat at a table that did not place the community on the menu, THANK YOU. . . To my residents who would answer the door when we knocked or who simply believe that we can realize our potential as a community, THANK YOU! My service of this community has been such an immense blessing, and I THANK YOU for allowing me to serve. In this New Year, I pray that we all have the courage, grit, strength, stamina, optimism & ability to expand our imaginations about what is possible in 2020 & beyond. God Bless all of you, & thank you for allowing me to serve you!

Here in Texas, climate change is at our front door. I saw firsthand Harvey's devastation, and because of climate change, storms like Harvey are no longer once in a generation events. That’s why it’s so disheartening that on Monday, the United States officially withdrew from the Paris climate agreement.  Here are the facts: the last five years are the warmest on record. Extreme weather events like hurricanes and flooding cost the United States $400 billion since 2014. This crisis isn’t going away. We need leaders who will plan, problem solve, and take action instead of burying their heads in the sand. Climate change feels like a scary, intractable problem. But Texans never back down from a challenge. It’s time for new leadership, and a strong way forward.

Here in Texas, climate change is at our front door. I saw firsthand Harvey's devastation, and because of climate change, storms like Harvey are no longer once in a generation events. That’s why it’s so disheartening that on Monday, the United States officially withdrew from the Paris climate agreement.  Here are the facts: the last five years are the warmest on record. Extreme weather events like hurricanes and flooding cost the United States $400 billion since 2014. This crisis isn’t going away. We need leaders who will plan, problem solve, and take action instead of burying their heads in the sand. Climate change feels like a scary, intractable problem. But Texans never back down from a challenge. It’s time for new leadership, and a strong way forward.

I know I’m not the likeliest candidate for U.S. Senate. Today I want to tell you a little more about the personal reasons behind my commitment to service. I lost my dad to cancer when I was 17 years old. He was diagnosed with cancer when I was in the 4th grade. As time went on and treatments did as well, I asked him many questions about his illness and treatments like, "who is paying for this?" and, "what happens if the insurance company says 'no' to the treatment?" Although my dad had access to high-quality, life-extending healthcare, so many Texas families do not -- and that's unacceptable. I had my father until my junior year of high school -- he passed away just months after he accompanied me on the field for homecoming at Eisenhower High School. Those extra years with my dad were pivotal for me in my formative years, and I am grateful for each extra day he was with me.
